captions.text:
When I went on
my first outdoor picnic,

The first time I heard
the sweetest voice

You can sit here
if you want.

<i>I had never seen anything</i>
<i>so beautiful in my life.</i>

Well, are you going to
sit down or aren't you?

Um, nothing at all,
thank you.

My legs are just
fine and dandy.

<i>I just sat next to her</i>
<i>on that bus</i>

<i>And had a conversation</i>
<i>all the way to school.</i>

My back's crooked
like a question mark.

<i>Next to mama, no one</i>
<i>ever talked to me</i>

Mama says, "stupid is
as stupid does."

<i>From that day on,</i>
<i>we was always together.</i>

<i>Jenny and me was</i>
<i>like peas and carrots.</i>

Come on, forrest,
you can do it.

Mama's going
to worry about me.

title: Forrest Gump (1/9) Movie CLIP - Peas and Carrots (1994) HD

comments.author: Gasner D

comments.text:
In my humble opinion, this is the greatest movie of all time. It touches 
every human emotion. It's sad, it's funny, it's ironic, it makes you both 
laugh and cry, it makes you angry, it makes you hurt, it makes you think, 
it makes you want to forgive, and it challenges you to examine your own 
life and your priorities. It's about love and pain and joy and hope. I 
really believe this movie can inspire someone to change their life if it's 
headed down the wrong path. It helped change mine. The writing, acting, 
directing, soundtrack and score are 10s across the board. What more can you 
ask for?﻿

comments.author: Amber Ridgdill

comments.text:
+Amber Ridgdill How could you, or anyone who hasn't studied that kind of 
thing, possibly attempt to judge people like that, even if you have 
experienced abuse? Maybe the reason some abused children turn out better 
than others because, some way or another, something or someone guided them 
to a better path, but in a way that they don't realise that something is 
having that kind of effect on them. Either way, you'd need a PsyD or 
similar to even come close to fully understanding people like Jenny.
comments.author: Steph S

comments.text:
It depends on how the child handles it once grown. Unfortunately a lot of 
people let those things shape who they become in a very bad way. As someone 
whose been through that, if you can manage to understand that it wasn't 
your fault, you'll generally turn out alright. That's not to say it's OK 
when that happens, only that there are lots of fucked up people in the 
world. Their actions shouldn't determine your life's outcome is all. It's a 
matter of willpower, and more often, spite.
comments.author: Amber Ridgdill

comments.text:
I was thinking about (I had taped it) showing my nephew it.  I can't find a 
rating on it. Is F. Gump considered under 13 or just normal pg? He is 9 
years old but loves to have more thoughtful things to watch. I used to 
enjoy pre-kids stuff but has matured a lot.  Do you think 9 is too young to 
watch this?﻿
comments.author: Anne Liesveld

comments.text: Forget how old he is. It's his maturity that matters.
comments.author: BrandontheMovieGuy

comments.text:
I can't imagine letting my niece watch R rated at 4-5. That is called 
irresponsible parenting. Wanting your kids to watch what you watch because 
it is "fun or popular with you and your friends" Now I feel really dumb 
thinking I was being a little conservative thinking my nephew wasn't mature 
enough to handle the adult aspects of this show. Apparently guidance to 
watch or not a movie means all that has to be present is an adult to make 
it ok to watch a movie for a 19 year old with a 4 year old.
comments.author: Anne Liesveld

comments.text:
My parents let me watch Jaws and Nightmare on Elm Street when I was 8. I 
turned out alright, I think. That was the 90's though, and of course as 
Stonewall Jack pointed out, things have changed. Maybe kids aren't prepared 
to see anything other than rainbows any more. I think 13 is a young adult 
and a lot of things are suitable. I saw Panic Room at 12 and wasn't scared 
by it even one bit. I first saw this movie when I was about 9-10. There 
wasn't anything weird about it, I think I just didn't understand some parts 
(like Forrest buying Apple stock), but the overall message and the 
relationship he has with Jenny, I really appreciated.
comments.author: CandleAshes

comments.text:
#1- It's Forest Gump.... You've seen it, use your adult judgement on 
whether or not you think your 9 year old should watch it, every kid is 
different. If you haven't seen it before, I don't know how, unless you're 
one of those teen moms and this movie is older than you are. It's not The 
Human Centipede or some cheesy 80's gore-fest movie. #2- You're on the 
internet, you could find the rating if you really wanted to in seconds 
rather than asking YouTube, as this is probably the absolute worst place to 
ask anything. That being said, it's PG-13. But that's early 90's PG-13 so 
by today's parenting standards it's probably rated X, as these days kids 
can't be exposed to anything other than pretty rainbows and unicorns, and 
parents can't even put their kid in a car without strapping them down like 
they're on Apollo 11. #3- Let your kid be a kid. As someone who grew up in 
the 80's and 90's, yes it's fine, and I can tell you that Forest Gump is 
the least of your concerns when it comes to worrying about what your kid 
watches.
comments.author: Stonewall Jack
